utterances.translation: I will talk about how people got married long ago.

utterances.transcript: hiist̓iʔaƛquuč ḥuu nay̓aqak̓aƛquu, ʔuḥ ʔaʔiič̓umʔi ʕaʕaasḥi yaqcḥinƛ̓aqƛukʔitq ḥaakʷaaƛ.
utterances.translation: It used to be the case that parents arranged for marriage long before [the actual marriage], when their daughter is a baby.
They would propose while [their daughter] was still a baby.
Then, the girl grew up and became a woman, menstruating for the first time.

utterances.transcript: ʔuyaaƛ ʔaḥʔaa ʕiict̓uuɬaƛ̓atquu hinʔaɬšiʔaƛ̓aɬ ʔan ɬuucmiičiƛ maatmaas. hinʔaɬšiƛ ʔan ɬuucmiičiƛ.
utterances.translation: When they gave a feast celebrating her first menstruation, people of the village recognized that she had become a woman.
The man’s side would go to ask for the girl, traveling to her village.
They would never stay (just) for one day.
They would be there for two weeks or one month.

utterances.transcript: qiičiƛ hiis c̓iiqaa, ʔuuqḥɬi qʷaaʔaqƛ̓itq čačumḥi ʔuʔaaɬuk ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i.
utterances.translation: They remained there on the beach for a long time chanting, saying how they will take care of the girl properly.

utterances.transcript: čuu, ʔam̓inʔaƛquuč, ƛaʔitap̓aƛquuč, hiiɬciiʕasʔap hiy̓atḥʔitq ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i.
utterances.translation: Now, when they first arrived, they would put up a stick in front of the girl’s house.

utterances.transcript: hiʔiisʔaƛ ʔaḥʔaa ƛaʔas ʔunic̓asʔaƛ ʔunic̓asʔitqʔaɬ, c̓iiqaa, ciiqciiqa.
utterances.translation: The stick remained there on the ground as long as they were there chanting and speaking.

utterances.transcript: waa, čuu, t̓apatšiʔaƛquu, ʔan ʔucḥinƛ̓aqƛuk ḥaakʷaaƛ.
utterances.translation: And then, they (the girl’s side) would think about whether their girl would marry him or not.
They (girl’s family) would take the stick into the house if they say “OK” to the proposal.
If they rejected the proposal, then they would break the stick in half and throw it out on the beach.
Now, at this time they would tell the man’s side, “Come inside.”
The man’s side stayed at the girl’s house, since their house was big.
They would be at the girl’s house and would do various things.

utterances.transcript: ʔumč̓aap huyaaɬ ʔutwii čaapxcuw̓atʔi — ʔi!, ɬuučcuw̓atʔi waaʔap̓is
utterances.translation: The would do entertainment dances, first the man’s side — oh no, the girl’s side, I should say.

utterances.transcript: huyaaɬšiƛ ʔumč̓aap, waa, ḥaacḥuuɬšiƛiny̓aƛ, čaačumpitapšiʔaƛ ʔaay̓uusḥhy̓umsukʔi čaapxcuw̓atʔi.
utterances.translation: They would do the entertainment dance. Then they would display their family rights and would give gifts [lit. making things proper (by giving things)] to the immediate family of the man’s side.
And then, the girl would take along the songs with her.

utterances.transcript: ʔaʔiiḥmisukʔiʔaɬ nuuknuuk huuɬhuuɬay̓ak ʔuucwaasʔaƛquu ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i, ʔucačiƛ hiy̓atḥšiƛ̓asʔitq.
utterances.translation: They let the girl take along with her their important songs for dances to the place she would live.
At this point the bride’s side tell [the man’s side] what she would take with her.

utterances.transcript: waa, ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ t̓aaqyay̓ap̓at ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i, sukʷiʔaƛ̓ič waaʔaƛquu.
utterances.translation: And they would make the girl stand up, and they would say [to the man’s side], “Come take her.”
The man’s side would stand up to go to take the girl.

utterances.transcript: ʔiiḥʔiiḥa ʔuušyuuya qʷaayac̓iiksnaʕaaɬ, ʔunaak̓aƛquu ḥaw̓iiḥ qʷayac̓iik sukʷiƛ̓as ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i.
utterances.translation: Sometimes they made a big deal out of it when taking the girl by using wolves if the chiefs had wolves.

utterances.transcript: hiišcuw̓aƛ̓atquu nanaʔiqsu t̓aaqyiiɬ ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i, waa, ƛawinsʔi c̓iiqaa, sukʷiƛ̓as ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i.
utterances.translation: The girl’s aunts would stand up on both sides of the bride, approach the girl chanting, and take the girl.
They would take her to the man’s side.
When they (the man’s side) took her, she would become their queen.

utterances.transcript: waa ʔuḥiičiʔaƛ čaapxcuw̓atʔi ʔumč̓aap, huuɬhuuɬa, waa hinkiicuƛiny̓aƛ.
utterances.translation: And it would be the man’s side to fun dances. And they would finish with headdress dances.
The girl also took along with her money as well as the songs.

utterances.transcript: ḥaʔukʷiʔaƛ čaapxcuw̓atʔi, ʔuyii yaana, huʔacaʔap ƛayamaɬaʔap ʔanasiɬa yaqʷiicwasʔitq ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i.
utterances.translation: The man’s side paid back by giving more money [to the girl’s family] than the girl brought with her.
They gave gifts in return to the woman’s side.
This is what they used to do a long time ago when she became their queen.
It was not allowed for the girl to leave [where she married to].
She would go to wear her husband lived.
There she made her home and had children.

utterances.transcript: ʔaniyaƛquu waɬsaap̓at ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i wiikiiɬʔaƛquu t̓aatn̓aʔis. ʔan ʔiiḥcamisukʷit t̓aatn̓anak̓at.
utterances.translation: The only times when they sent the girl home was when she did not produce children, because it is very important to have children.

utterances.transcript: waa, waḥkʷačiƛquu waɬšiƛquu ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i, huʔacaʔap̓aƛquu ʔaʔiič̓umʔi.
utterances.translation: And if they separated and the girl went back home, the [girl’s] parents would bring her back [to the husband’s house].

utterances.transcript: huʔacaʔap ʔiiḥʔiiḥa ʔuuḥʷʼaɬ qʷayac̓iik huʔacaʔap hiy̓atḥʔaƛ̓itq. huʔacḥinup.
utterances.translation: They would bring her back to her current residence (the place she married to), making a big deal out of it by using wolves. They would bring her back to her husband.
They never let them part.
It was important for a man to have a wife.
That was how our ways were.
It was a serious matter.

utterances.transcript: ʔaniyumtƛaʔaaɬ huʔacaʔap̓at ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i qʷiqʷiiqsak, wiikmaʕuk̓ʷaƛquu, wic̓ikquu kuučiɬ, wic̓ikquu haaʔumtaq.
utterances.translation: The only time they would send the girl back to her in-laws was when she did not know how to do anything, such as filleting fish and cooking.
They would bring her back to her home.

utterances.transcript: maa sukʷiʔič waa, ʔuḥtaa ʔumʔiiqsuʔi n̓uw̓iiqsuʔi.
utterances.translation: They would say to her mother and father, “Here, take her.”
They would say, “She doesn’t know anything. Teach her.”
They would send her home and say, “Bring her back [to us] when she learns to do things.”

utterances.transcript: ʔan ʔiiḥcamisukʷit ḥaatḥakʷaƛ, hiišiɬʔap̓anit huḥtak ḥaatḥakʷaƛ, kuučiɬ, n̓iiƛn̓iiya, paaskitiiɬ waa hihiqtup.
utterances.translation: [That was] because it was important for the girls to have learned how to fillet fish, sew, make baskets, and so on.
So, she would start having children at her new house.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaa qʷisḥqaač̓ina kʷiikʷiisḥinčiƛ, ciiqciiqa ʔunw̓iiƛḥ ʔan kʷiscačiƛitʔaaɬ ḥaakʷaaƛ̓i ḥuu, histaqšiʔaƛquu, ƛaʔuukʷiʔatḥ ʔucačiƛ qaay̓uuk̓ʷatḥ.
utterances.translation: That must be the reason why we have come to speak different dialects — because girls used to go to different places from Clayoquot to Kyuquot.

utterances.transcript: wik č̓in̓uqƛ ʔan qʷaačiiɬʔat ʔuḥʔat ʔaʔiič̓umʔak.
utterances.translation: They never refused because they were taught by their parents [not to].
Well, that is all I am going to say.
